awd_titl_txt: The Geometry and Topology of the Jones Polynomial
awd_abstract_narration:
This National Science Foundation funded project is focused on PIs' cutting-edge research in Quantum Topology, an area of mathematics that involves three-dimensional shapes that are called three-manifolds and knotted circles within them. Knots appear naturally in the process of replication of DNA, a fundamental part of life. They also appear in theoretical and practical models of quantum computation, using pioneering work of Jones and Freedman, two mathematicians decorated by the highest honor in Mathematics, namely a Fields Medal. Those models of quantum computation, if realized, may bring changes to the world comparable to the invention of electricity.

This research project in Quantum Topology links quantum field theory to topology in dimensions three and four, leading to powerful invariants of knots and three-manifolds that include the Jones polynomial, the 3D-index, state-sums and state-integrals. The PI and the co-PI have had substantial results on the formulation and proof of long-standing conjectures in this area, and propose to study key unsolved problems. The proposal is modern, interdisciplinary and employs methods in topology, geometry, algebra, number theory, analysis, quantum field theory and combinatorics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This grant funded successful research in problems relating the geometry, topology, number theory and physics of the Jones polynomial, and more generally quantum invariants of knots and 3-manifolds. The grant has partially funded 17 publications, including papers appeared in top journals like Inventiones Math. and Duke Math. Journal.

The grant was originally joint with S. Garoufalidis, who was the PI, and the current PI was the co-PI. Since S. Garoufalidis left in 2019, the co-PI became the PI of the grant.

The PI introduced, and then with colleagues developed the theory of stated skein algebra which has now become a main tool in the study of skein algebra and quantum topology. The stated skein algebra allows to decompose the usual skein modules into small pieces and study them individually. Many important results in the theory have been obtained via the stated skein algebra. For example, it allows to extend the quantum trace homomorphism, first constructed by Bonahon and Wong for the simplest Lie algebra sl2 using difficult direct calculations, to a wider class of surfaces and to higher Lie algebras. Many young mathematicians since then also study and further develop the theory of stated skein algebras.

In joint work with C. Frohman and J. Kania-Bartoszynska the PI proved the unicity theorem for representations of skein algebras. The theorem and its generalizations have been playing an important role in the ongoing constructions of hyperbolic topological quantum field theories.  In a joint work with Garoufalidis and Lauda, the PI proved that the HOMFLYPT polynomial is q-holonomic, a statement long conjectured in physics. The result puts the AJ conjecture for higher order Lie algebras on a firm mathematical ground.

The broader impacts include training of graduate and undergraduate students, conference organizations, and expository work. During the grant period the PI supervised two PhD students who defended their theses in 2019 and 2023, mentored one postdoc and supervised two undergraduate students. The PI was a co-organizer of 5 conferences. In particular, he was the main organizer of a weeklong international conference and a weeklong summer school in Vietnam in 2019. The PI had given minicourses at 8 workshops, contributing to the education of PhD students and young postdoc all over the world.

 


Last Modified: 07/23/2024
Modified by: Thang Le
